column2: you can use a stick to pull the person to safety. Never get into the water to try and rescue someone. If you get into the water
column3: you could also drown. If the person who needs help is too far away from you to reach with a stick
column4: you can throw something that floats. Throw something they can hold on to and use to stay above the water. You could throw a soccer ball or an empty five-litre plastic container. If someone needs rescuing from water
column5: ask a lifeguard or adult for help. Never go into the water to try and rescue someone yourself. You can also call the free national emergency number
column7: from a cell phone or a landline. If someone is rescued from the water and they are not breathing
column8: you should call 112 for help. You can then start Hands-on CPR by pushing hard and fast in the centre of their chest. Do not practice this on a friend! You can find out more from the National Sea Rescue Institute.
